node.text:
Did you know Yellowstone removes hazard trees from campgrounds and picnic areas? Like all living things, trees have a life cycle and eventually die.  Employees like Brian reduce the risk of personal injury or property damage by identifying the trees with the highest potential for failure and removing them before they cause problems. Salvaged wood is used for various projects throughout the park.

“During a wind storm a few years ago, we had a live tree fall on a campground host’s RV. Thankfully, everyone was OK, but the RV was totaled. It was a great reminder of the importance of this work to keep people safe.” –Brian Teets, Resource Management Coordinator #WhatWeDoWednesdays

node.title: Minute Out In It - Hazard Tree Crew

node.text:
Yellowstone Volcano Observatory Scientist-in-Charge Mike Poland provides an update on activity in Yellowstone during the month of June 2021 from the boardwalk near Echinus Geyser (the largest acid geyser in the world!).

The Yellowstone Seismic Network located 445 earthquakes in the Yellowstone National Park region. Subsidence of Yellowstone Caldera, which has been ongoing since 2015, slowed during May/June 2021 reflecting seasonal groundwater recharge. And for the first time since April 2018, Steamboat Geyser did not have any water eruptions during a calendar month. Overall, the time between eruptions has been lengthening, which may be an indication that the current cycle of activity at the geyser is coming to a close. Dr. Poland walks you through the publicly-available data and explains recent events.

Thank you to our colleagues at @usgsvolcanoes for the latest monthly update!

node.title: Yellowstone Volcano Observatory Monthly Update - July 1, 2021

node.text: Yellowstone’s Fire Safety Officer, John Cataldo, discusses current fire danger, fire restrictions, and fire management procedures ahead of the busy Fourth of July weekend.

node.title: Fire Safety with John Cataldo, Yellowstone’s Fire Management Officer

node.text: If you've visited Yellowstone in recent years, it's likely you've come across a construction project or two. This video answers the question we often receive, "What's with all the construction in Yellowstone?"

node.text:
Mike Poland, scientist-in-charge at the Yellowstone Volcano Observatory, provides an update on activity during the month of May, which included 72 located earthquakes, continuation of ground deformation trends, and two water eruptions at Steamboat Geyser.

Thanks to our colleagues at @usgsvolcanoes for the latest monthly update!

node.title: Yellowstone Volcano Observatory Monthly Update - June 1, 2021

node.text:
News Release: If you plan to travel to Yellowstone National Park this summer, plan ahead and recreate responsibly to protect yourself and this wild and awe-inspiring place.

Summer is Yellowstone’s most popular season. Expect long lines at entrance stations, extremely busy facilities and destinations, as well as delayed travel times due to heavy traffic and wildlife jams. If you want a less-crowded experience, arrive early or stay late and avoid main attractions such as Old Faithful, Grand Prismatic Spring, the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone and Norris Geyser Basin during peak hours.

To learn more about tips for planning a park visit this summer and how to #RecreateResponsibly, visit the link in our bio!

node.title: Visiting Yellowstone this summer? Plan ahead and recreate responsibly!

node.text:
It's May, the snow is melting, and the roads are mostly open, so it's time for geologists, geophysicists, and geochemists to head into Yellowstone to start projects they have been planning for the last several months. Mike Poland, the scientist-in-charge of the Yellowstone Volcano Observatory, talks about future field plans and recent activity at Yellowstone.

Thanks to our colleagues at @@usgsvolcanoes for the latest monthly update!

For closed captions and to read the full transcript, visit the link in our bio.

node.title: Yellowstone Volcano Observatory Monthly Update - May 1, 2021

node.text:
There are thousands of volcanic features distributed throughout the southwest United States, which are grouped together in volcanic fields. The Yellowstone Volcano Observatory (YVO) monitors these volcanoes using a combination of techniques. While YVO hasn’t seen anything to suggest magma is on the move, the area is stretched and pulled apart to produce numerous tectonic earthquakes. YVO keeps an eye on these volcanoes and the Yellowstone Volcano, as described in this monthly video update by Mike Poland, YVO scientist-in-charge.

Thanks to our friends at @usgsvolcanoes for the latest monthly update!

For closed captions and to read the full transcript, visit the link in our bio.

node.title: Yellowstone Volcano Observatory Monthly Update - April 1, 2021

node.text:
Have you ever wondered how we get park roads snow-free for your spring visit?

Beginning this past Monday evening, all oversnow travel via snowmobile/snowcoach ended to allow for our crews to begin clearing a winter's worth of snow. Although most park roads will be closed for the next few weeks, the road between the North and Northeast entrances remains open to personal vehicles year-round, weather-permitting.

Be sure to check the status of roads before venturing into the park by signing up to receive Yellowstone road alerts on your mobile phone by texting "82190" to 888-777, calling 307-344-2117 to listen to a recorded message, or checking our park roads page on our website: nps.gov/yell.

To watch this video with closed captions, visit the link in our bio.

node.text:
News Release: On Saturday, March 13, a pilot supporting park wildlife studies saw the first grizzly bear of 2021. From the air, the pilot watched the bear interact with wolves at a carcass in the northern part of the park. This is the first sighting of a grizzly bear in the park this year, although tracks have been seen on several occasions in the last two weeks.

The first bear sighting of 2020 occurred on March 7.

To learn more about bear safety and read the full news release, visit: go.nps.gov/21005 (link in our bio).

Video description: A grizzly bear meanders down trails and digs in meadows searching for food after emerging from hibernation.

National parks are bustling this year. For a safe and enjoyable visit, allow extra time to get from one place to another. And remember, you are sharing the roads with not only people, but wildlife too! 

Learn more tips for a safe and memorable visit at https://www.nps.gov/yell/planyourvisit/index.htm

node.text:
Trumpeter swans on Trip Day!

Trip Day Thursday
Norris Geyser Basin to Mammoth Hot Springs
 
The drive between these two thermal basins contains many roadside gems, including the steaming Roaring Mountain fumaroles near Norris and the cascading Rustic Falls beside Golden Gate near Mammoth. But in your haste to see these areas, you can easily miss spotting one of the park’s most impressive birds: the trumpeter swan (Cygnus buccinator). Named for its resonant call, the trumpeter swan is North America’s largest wild waterfowl, with a wingspan of up to eight feet. Twenty-seven resident swans were known to be in Yellowstone in 2019, including three territorial pairs, which mate for life. One of these pairs can be spotted at Swan Lake, nestled under an incredible view of the Gallatin Mountains. The Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem was crucial to the trumpeter swan’s survival in the Lower 48 states; by the 1930s, a small population of 70 remaining swans localized within and around the park due to habitat loss and hunting elsewhere. With intensive management, this initial population provided the basis for nationwide swan recovery later in the century. Watch these majestic creatures from a great distance through scopes or binoculars; if disturbed by humans, these nationally protected birds can fail to hatch their eggs. 
 
#TripDayThursday #Yellowstone #NationalParks

News Release: Beginning Sunday, August 1, people may apply to the 2021-2022 winter lottery for permits to snowmobile in Yellowstone without a commercial guide. Authorized in 2013, the Non-Commercially Guided Snowmobile Access Program allows one group of up to five snowmobiles to enter Yellowstone from each of its four winter entrances per day.

Learn more: go.nps.gov/21022 (link in bio)

node.text:
Did you know Yellowstone maintains 300 intelligent alarms systems? In accordance with the National Fire Alarm Code, employees like Dan are certified to design, install, inspect, and repair park alarm systems upon completion of a rigorous accreditation program.

“There’s no room for error when dealing with fire safety. When smoke or fire is detected, alarms must activate immediately and notify the people inside the building and first responders 100% of the time.” –Dan Brown, Electronics Technician #WhatWeDoWednesdays

Photo: Dan Brown, electronics technician, working on a alarm panel.

node.text:
#TipTuesday: UV exposure at high elevations is significantly greater than at sea level, so don’t forget to bring sunscreen, a sun hat, and outerwear with UV protection when you visit!

Approximate elevations at popular sight-seeing areas in the park include: Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone River - 8,000 ft: Old Faithful Geyser - 7,660 ft; Mammoth Hot Springs - 6,235 ft; and Yellowstone Lake - 7,742 ft.

node.text:
News Release: Effective Saturday, July 24, Yellowstone National Park’s rivers and streams will close to fishing in the afternoon and evening due to high-water temperatures and unprecedented low stream flows. This closure will protect the park’s native and wild trout fisheries.

What will be closed?
- Fishing on rivers and streams will be prohibited from 2 p.m. to sunrise the following day.
- The closure will remain in effect until further notice.

What will be open?
- Anglers can fish from sunrise to 2 p.m.
- Yellowstone Lake and other lakes will remain open to fishing from sunrise to sunset as specified in the Fishing Regulations booklet.

Water temperatures have exceeded 68 degrees Fahrenheit (20 degrees Celsius) in recent days, and flows on many rivers are approaching historic lows. These conditions are extremely stressful and can be fatal to fish. The extended forecast calls for continued hot and dry conditions with a slight chance of isolated afternoon thunderstorms, which contribute to continued low stream flows and high-water temperatures.

Anglers: Please fish during the coolest times of day and land fish quickly. Do not play hooked trout to exhaustion. Gently handle fish in the water as much as possible and let them recover before release. Your cooperation will protect the park’s fisheries and may preclude the need to prohibit fishing at all times of the day on some rivers and streams if conditions worsen.

Learn more: go.nps.gov/21021 (link in bio)

node.text:
Trip Day takes on a colossal thermal feature!

Trip Day Thursday
Canyon Village to Norris Geyser Basin
 
Norris Geyser Basin, a land of extremes, is known for being the oldest, hottest, most acidic, and most dynamic of Yellowstone’s thermal areas. The bright green and red-orange thermophilic hues give this basin a distinct color palette, providing visual evidence of a large variety of microscopic organisms thriving under intense conditions. Since 2019, Norris has seen dynamic activity surrounding the world’s tallest active geyser, Steamboat Geyser; its rare major eruptions shoot water into the air more than 300 feet (91 m)! Steamboat Geyser is sporadic in its eruptions, with infrequent activity followed by periods of dormancy. If you stroll the boardwalks to see Steamboat Geyser for yourself, you may only see it in its steam phase, but evidence of recent eruptions may be found. Runoff and water discharge from the geyser can be so high that mud and debris collect under or even on boardwalks nearby. 
 
#TripDayThursday #Yellowstone #NationalParks

node.text:
Did you know Yellowstone has a growing research library with over 20,000 books, movies, music, and articles? Employees like Sarah dig into our collections to help people learn about the area’s history, wildlife, geography, and unique stories. Call, email, or stop by the Heritage and Research Center next time you’re in the area!

“You never know what people are going to ask--it could be about the remains of a structure they saw along a trail or what elk eat in the winter. It's rewarding to help people find new connections with Yellowstone through the topics that interest them the most." –Sarah Marino, Research Librarian #WhatWeDoWednesdays
